notes: The UAE has removed the entry permit requirement for residents who were stuck abroad due to the coronavirus pandemic, as part of the countryâs push to allow their safe return.  Under the new policy, returning residents will automatically be granted pre-approval but will be required to submit a negative COVID-19 PCR test result from a screening done not more than 96 hours before arriving in the UAE.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200812192533/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1718351/middle-east

The capacity of mosques will increase to 50%, and worshippers will be required to distance (2 meters). See Emirates News Agency website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200819085129/https://wam.ae/en/details/1395302857282

As of August 6th, âgyms and sports halls, outdoor sports fields, and swimming poolsâ re-opened in Bahrain. See Bahrain News Agency website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822152930/https://www.bna.bh/en/HRHPremierissuedEdict33/HMKingissuesdecrees50,51,52/HRHtheCrownPrinceThenextphaseofcombatingCOVID19callsforcontinueddetermination.aspx?cms=q8FmFJgiscL2fwIzON1%2BDtwvEPGzSUbU2cillExCncM%3D However, other workplaces remain closed, including sheesha cafÃ©s and training institutes. On August 12th, The Kingdom of Bahrain Ministry of Health released a Covid-19 news update: âPrayers at mosques, collective worship and religious assemblies will remain suspended, the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs has said. The suspension will be maintained until the rate of the coronavirus (COVID-19) will decrease to the levels set by the competent authorities.â See website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822161233/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4322

âGatherings of more than five individuals on roads, yards, public beaches, parks, and other public places are prohibited, including religious gatherings.â See Covid-19 information on the US Embassy in Bahrain website, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20200822163848/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Bahrainâs public transport is still operating without significantly reduced volume/ route/ means of transport available, and it remains mandatory for all individuals to wear a face mask while using public transportation and practice social distancing. See Covid-19 information on the US Embassy in Bahrain website, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20200822163848/https://bh.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry to Bahrain remains ârestricted to Bahraini citizens, residents, and some other categoriesâ. See UK Government website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822174507/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bahrain

The Bahrain government paid the salaries of Bahraini citizens working in the private sector for April, May and June, 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20200822182627/https://youth.moh.gov.bh/News/Details/3982 On July 11th, The Minister of Labour and Social Development, Jameel bin Mohammed Ali Humaidan, âexplained the governmentâs [additional] commitment to paying 50% of the salaries of insured Bahrainis in the most adversely affected enterprises in the private sector for a period of three months, starting from July 2020, from the Unemployment Insurance Fund.â See Bahrain News Agency website, archived: http://web.archive.org/web/20200822181250/https://www.bna.bh/en/LabourMinistryannouncescriteriafor50paymentofBahrainiprivatesectorworkers.aspx?cms=q8FmFJgiscL2fwIzON1%2BDruu3Yio84ebkJBheG2qYL0%3D

The Bahrain government paid the electricity and water bills for Bahraini individuals and companies for April, May, and June. On June 29th, authorities approved new measures to âextend the payment of electricity and water bills for Bahrainis for a further three months starting in July 2020â. Also, at end-July 2020 the authorities approved a new measure âexempting households from paying municipality fees on their first residence for three monthsâ. Furthermore, on March 17th, the Central Bank of Bahrain (CBB) requested âbanks to offer a six-month deferral of repayments without interest or penalty and to refrain from blocking customersâ accounts if a customer has lost his or her employmentâ. This sixth-month deferral period is still current. See IMF website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822204627/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Kingdom of Bahrain Ministry of Health website homepage, and social media accounts, remain focused on their âPublic Awareness Campaign to Combat Coronavirus (COVID-19)â. See Ministry of Health website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822213821/https://www.moh.gov.bh/?lang=en

Bahrain is still running open public testing, including via. drive-through. On August 20th Bahrainâs âMinistry of Health reported that the Kingdom had conducted over one million COVID-19 PCR diagnostic tests. In an update on the Kingdomâs COVID-19 response, Bahrainâs Minister of Health Faeqa bint Saeed Alsaleh, confirmed the milestone figure had been reached as part of the âTrace, Test, Treatâ strategy that has involved proactive testing on a scale well above many other countries. The Minister highlighted this strategy has resulted in Bahrain conducting 675 tests per 1,000 people, one of the highest rates in the world.â See Ministry of Health website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200822220631/https://www.moh.gov.bh/COVID19/Details/4341

Comprehensive contact tracing is ongoing, in coordination with the Ministry of Interior. https://web.archive.org/web/20200822213821/https://www.moh.gov.bh/?lang=en See the Ministry of Healthâs contact tracing update for the 13th-19th August 2020, archived: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.moh.gov.bh/Covid19/ContactTracing1

Schools are currently closed in Bahrain but will be reopening in September. On August 17, the Kingdom of Bahrain Ministry of Education released statements that âadministrative and teaching staff will resume work on September 6 as previously announcedâ and âstudents would return to schools on September 16â. However, âparents will still have the option to choose between school attendance or online learning.â See Bahrain News Agency website, archived:Â https://web.archive.org/web/20200822144958/https://www.bna.bh/en/EducationMinistryschoolyeartostartinSeptember.aspx?cms=q8FmFJgiscL2fwIzON1%2BDuOWje6BIKfuUp%2FcbourquE%3D

No policy change found. Since 10 May, a presidential decree has banned gatherings of more than 10 people. Therefore this policy should be coded as 4G (Gatherings of 10 people or less are permitted countrywide).    Source:   UN Djibouti, "COVID-19 Situation Report #7 - 10 MAY"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200522101134/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Djibouti%20COVID19%20Sitrep%207.pdf

No policy change. Code downgraded from 1 to 0, because the policy which was quoted for justifying the value "1" consisted in handing out allowances to workers and freezing the payment of social contributions for employers. Therefore this policy does not fall under indicator E2, which tracks debt and contract relief for households.    Source:  "La Nation" newspaper ; article on the President's speech regarding Djibouti's response to the pandemic, including economic policies (French)  http://archive.fo/5SGBw#selection-2129.344-2129.548

As of 6 August, according to a UN report, tests are carried out on people presenting at least one symptomatology related to the case definition. Moreover, the trend of number of tests performed is gradually decreasing (279 daily),  which may be explained by the recent celebration of the religious holiday of aid el Adha.    Source:  UN in Djibouti, COVID-19 Situation Report #13 (24 July â 6 August), p. 2  https://web.archive.org/web/20200822101920/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Djibouti%20COVID19%20Sitrep%2013.pdf    According to the IMF, "the government continues to target those who have potentially been in contact with people who have tested positive".    Source:  IMF policy tracker on COVID-19 response  https://web.archive.org/web/20200822095755/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Travellers coming to Djibouti are still being screened for COVID-19. According to the Ministry of Health (MoH), between 7 July and 11 August, 2761 people have been tested at the country's airport and 129 of these came back positive.    Source:  Weekly MoH press release on aeroport COVID-19 screening (French)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200822092145/https://www.facebook.com/minister.sante.dj/photos/a.1390385961000334/3333935503312027/?type=3&theater=

Non-Egyptian arrivals will require a negative PCR test for coronavirus no more than 72 hours before entering the country. The regulation excludes Arab and foreign tourists arriving on direct flights to costal governorates, but will be forbidden to enter Cairo without the test. See news website, Arab News, archived, https://web.archive.org/web/20200822150347/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1717056/middle-east

On August 15, the Government of Iraq amended the curfew. A partial curfew is in effect seven days a week from 10:00 pm to 5:00am.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820102320/https://iq.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Destinations are grouped into âGreenâ and âRedâ locations. If you arrive from a âRedâ location, you will have to go into isolation. If you arrive from a âGreenâ location, there is not need to isolate, as long as you did not stay in a âRedâ location during a 14-day period before your flight to Israel. See Ministry of Health website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200818221823/https://www.gov.il/en/Departments/DynamicCollectors/green-red-countries?skip=0

On August 18, Kuwait will begin phase-four of a five phase plan to return the country to normality.  Gyms, salons, health clubs and barber shops to resume business    It is allowed to return to the workplace in government agencies and the private sector with a percentage of more than 50% of the workers at the headquarters. It is necessary and imperative that all activities assess their ability to operate remotely and adhere to this throughout the period of the pandemic, regardless of the general level of risk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200821012951/https://corona.e.gov.kw/Re-Open-PhaseIV-En.pdf

Compliance with general health requirements (mentioned in Article 1).  Maintaining periodic cleaning and disinfection procedures. The driver and passengers must always wear masks. It is also forbidden to ride for those who do not wear a mask.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200821012951/https://corona.e.gov.kw/Re-Open-PhaseIV-En.pdf

23rd August 2020, Moroccoâs authorities announced the closure of all the beaches on the coast of the communes of Sidi Rahal Chati and Soualem Trifia in Berrechid, 38.1 kilometers from Casablanca and other beaches in Casablanca, Mohammedia, Benslimane, including Bouznika beach. The decision is part of a series of actions by Moroccan authorities to  straighten preventive measures and halt the spread of COVID-19.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200827204222/https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2020/08/316318/morocco-closes-more-beaches-to-contain-covid-19-spread/

As of 8th August 2020, Oman has lifted national lockdown, except for the governorate of Dhofar. night restrictions will remain for about one week, starting Aug. 8, with unnecessary travel not allowed from 9p.m. until 5a.m.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820124507/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1716306/middle-east

As of 8th August 2020, interstate travel will be permitted, except for to and from the governorate of Dhofar which remains under lockdown until further notice. https://web.archive.org/web/20200820124507/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1716306/middle-east

From 15th August 2020, Oman ends nationwide night-time curfew, with the exception of Dhofar which remains under lockdown.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820125836/https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2132813-oman-ends-nationwide-nighttime-curfew

From 15th August 2020, Oman ends nationwide night-time curfew, with the exception of Dhofar which remains under lockdown.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820125836/https://www.argusmedia.com/en/news/2132813-oman-ends-nationwide-nighttime-curfew

As of 18th August 2020, Oman's Supreme Committee announced today the fifth batch of businesses are allowed to open now, while adhering to the COVID-19 precautions. Muttrah souq, a bustling market place for traditional and modern wares that had been closed for some time, will now be open.  Other businesses that will be open are restaurants, gyms and swimming pools inside hotel establishments, fish markets across all governorates, commercial activities that are run inside traditional markets, newspaper and magazine printing, special training activities approved by the Ministry of Manpower, playgrounds for the purpose of training national teams for regional and international events to be used by the national football team, national junior team, Oman national futsal team, Dhofar sports club, tennis playground for the general category, sale of phone sim cards, car wash centres, sale of tobacco and its products, tentsâ sale and tailoring shops.    Even though the international and tourists restaurants are allowed to open, sale of shisha and alcoholic drinks are not allowed to be served. The food courts at shopping malls will also remain closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820130150/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/oman/omans-muttrah-souq-newspaper-print-editions-to-open-from-tuesday-1.1597678533221

According Palestinian government spoke-person, " Palestinian authorities have lifted the weekly lockdown and eased the tight precautionary measures imposed in the West Bank to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.The government will now allow all economic activities on weekends with public health safety measures in place. Palestinian government spokeperson Milhem also said that the government would allow Friday prayers in public squares, but they have to take all preventive measures such as social distancing and wearing facemasks and gloves.However, he said that the government would keep wedding and mourning halls closed and ban all other kinds of popular indoor gatherings to avoid any new infections.
